If I knewe any way more dutifull then other,
to give her Ma
tie

r
, I would

But because this grace doth come unto me, by

r

t

endevo
rs
I may give her Ma
tie
best content,
I am to pray yo
w
most humbly, to undertake
in my behalf (and I hope to perfourme it to
yo
r
full satisfaction) that I will never lette
slippe, in w
at
soever I am able, any part of any
service,
at may be gratefull to her Hig
nes
.
It was a grievous corrosive unto me,
that was written from yo
r
L. about the
weakenesse of
e companies,
at were sent from
this place for
e siege of
Rouen.
Whiche also
moveth me
e more, for
at I feare at other
times, and in other like causes, some suche
offenses may be taken, as (submitting it
further to yo
r
L. consideration) I am not
any way to answear. For I had never
yet any charge, sins my first comming hither,
nether from
e LL. of
e Councel, nor yet
from yo
r
L. by letter or otherwise, to deale
in any mater appertening to
e Musters. I
had never no copie sent unto me, as there was
to other officers, of any orders or instructions,
that were at any time sent
hither,
as there were at
sundrie times, for divers speciall reformations.
fol.13v
For whiche I could not but presume, that it was
not any way intended, that I should meddle with
those affaires. And wheras by
e last newe
Establishement, for
e distribution of her Ma
ties
paies (wherof in like sort I have had no copie
sent unto me) it is ordened that 3 bookes should
be kept by
e Commissaries, to be sent at
e ende
of every 6 monethes, to
M
r
Wilkes
, to
e T
re
r
and to me, and
at to me to be presented to the
Councel of state
, it was never yet perfourmed
by any towardes me. Yet though I had no or-
der, nor letter about it, I would not have omit-
ted to calle upon them for it, but
at
e Councel
of state hath alwaies made me answear, that
they can not accept of any Musters, but suche
as are passed aswell by their owne, as by her
Ma
ties
Commissaries, and in one kinde of order
w
t
out
e allowance of
e dead paies, and of sun-
drie other pointes, w
ch
are otherwise sette downe
in her Ma
ties
orders, then they will be persua
ded to practise or approve. M
r
Wilkes can
report unto yo
r
L. their precise proceeding
in
at respect, w
ch
is also specified by
e Apo-
stilles of
e states to his last Propositions.
It may happely be,
at yo
r
L. doth conceave, that
being heere in place, I might have knowen by
relation, or by some other ready meanes,
e strength
of every company. But I doe assure yo
r
L.
it is not possible for me, not having
e oppor-
tunitie to see an Englishe company, but when
they come to service, and when
e Councel is pre
sent, w
ch
is never but in sommer, and then
very seeldome: and yet of those
at are imploied
in
e feelde, there is hardly
e third of her Ma
ties
forces. My best intelligence for
e state of
e companies
fol.14r
might come from
e Commissaries of
e Musters,
but their usual residence is so farre from the
Hage,
at
e
Brille
sette a part, I can hardly
send to the neerest unto me, and be sure of his
answear, under eight or nine daies.
Moreover because I greatly douted, lest
e forsaid
companies would be founde very weake, for
at
I knewe they had bin spent, partly by service
this sommer, partly by sicknes, and no supplies
sent over, besides
e nombers, that would flie
from their Captaines, before they came to em-
barking, if yow please to calle it to minde, I
did signifie in my letter of
e 20 of No
v
at
for
e renforcement of
e troupes, some supplie
would be needefull to be sent unto
Diepe.
There are at this present, as I writte
to yo
r
L. in my last, twenty Enseignes of these
contreis, that attend but a winde to be shipped
for
France,
of w
ch
there are 5 at
e least of 200
in a bande, and
e rest of 150 and 130 so as
being complete they might reche to
e nomber
of 3000 at
e lest, and yet by reason of the
forsaid accidents this last sommer, it is generally
supposed,
at they will scantly amount to 2000
in all, w
ch
will scarcely prove so good a recke-
ning as of
e Englishe troupes: considering
at
e Dutche companies have no allowance of
dead paies. I take litle pleasure
to putt yo
r
L. to this trouble, to hearcken to
e
reasons of my privat defense: but I beseeche yo
w
to impute it to mine earnest desire, not to seeme
any other then I will be alwaies, and I trust
I have bin hitherto, w
ch
is as carefull to acquite,
what my duty shall require, as can be expected
at my handes. Yo
r
L. I am sure shall never
fol.14v
have good cause to be otherwise persuaded: as
nowe I hope, in this point of
e companies de-
fectes, yow are better informed of my dealing,
and will vouchesafe in
at respect, to remove
every sparkle of her Ma
ties
displeasure. But
if I shall at any time receave any maner of
charge in regard of
e Musters, whereby it may
not be conceaved, that I meddle by intrusion
in
e offices of others ether heere or at home,
there shall nothing be wanting to
e diligent
perfourmance of
at her Hig
nes
shall commaund.
For hitherto in truth I have alwaies understoode,
that M
r
Wilkes had a special Commission, to
examine
e proceedinges of
e Englishe Commissaries,
and to looke into all maters beloning to the
Musters: for w
ch
cause, and for
at I was never
required, as likewise that
e Governo
rs
of
garrisons and others (who ought to have
e
care to keepe
eir companies complete, and
may easely doe it, having them alwaies in
their sight) might not t hinke me over busie
in
e affaires of their charge, I alwaies thought
I might be excused, if I should not deale
any further, then I was specially autorised.
Astouching those Musters, whiche
my LL. of
e Councel are desirous, should be
passed by
e officers of
e states, I have writ-
ten an answear in a letter a part, whiche
yo
r
L. will be pleased to deliver unto them.
For an answear to
e letter
w
ch
was written from
Mons
r
de Bilandt
one of
e
Empero
rs
Ambassado
rs
at
Brussels,
wherof I made mention in my last to yo
r
L.
it is nowe resolved,
at he shall have licence
to come hither. The deputies of
e General states
fol.15r
of whose recesse I have written in my former
letters, are not yet returned: but
e Councel
of state, to whome
e forsaid Ambassado
r
ad-
dressed his letter aswel as to
e states, have
sent a Passeport unto him. They have ende-
voured hitherto, by suche devises and excuses,
as I have alwaies imparted by my letters to
yo
r
L. to stoppe
e comming hither of any of
those Ambassado
rs
. Nowe notw
t
standing
at
accesse is required but for one of their nomber,
w
ch
is also reputed an honest favourer of their
cause, it is thought by this Councel,
at the ad-
mission of him, will serve them for a colour,
to shake of
e rest, and yet to satisfie the
Empero
r
and
e Princes of Germany, as-
touching their desire to come to a Pacification.
For seing there is no meeting of
e General
states, to whome it properly belongeth, to give
audience and answear, in affaires of that
nature, it is considered
at this Councel may
very well refuse it, as having no autoritie to
answear an Ambassado
r
, and yet by worde
of mouth, and by way of communication (for
happely by writing they might be more bounde
and entangled then they would be) they may
bothe make an excuse in
e behalf of
e states,
for
at
e Ambassado
rs
were not hitherto ad-
mitted, by reason of their recesse, and notifie
w
t
all what maner of peace they doe minde to
embrace: wherein they thinke
at
bothe
e con-
treis turne may be served both for answearing
e Empero
r
, and for cleanly casting of the
Ambassado
rs
Proposition, and likewise for
drawing somwhat in conference of
e Enemies
drfit in
e moving of this Treaty: and all

e Actions of
e Councel in causes surpas-
sing
e autoritie of their college, are not any

It is conditioned in
e forsaid Passeport,
that Mons
r
de Bilandt, must come forward
w
t
out delay, and not to bring w
t
him above 12
persons. There is also order taken,
at comming
to
Lillo,

e

And thus for this present I
